channel.title: Guitars and finger length
channel.description:
mmk strate 2 point. i has small fingers :rolleyes:
Well i researched it a bit and it seems more like stretching your fingers is the problem and as i don't own a guitar i can only imagine. I noticed people measure their hands from thumb to pinky, so i did. 6.5'' Will i encounter any problems with a 36'' guitar (Im about 4ft 8-5'')?

Im actually starting to like it Something unique to do in my spare time. It has a bigger sense of accomplishment when you get a tune right

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @slayer215 slayer215
item.description:
@slayer215 wrote:

You should get a chromatic tuner if you dont have one, Korg makes a nice cheap one thats at every guitar store, looks like this

amazon.com

Amazon.com: Korg CA-30 Chromatic Tuner: Musical Instruments

The Korg CA30 is a top-selling chromatic tuner with high accuracy and loads of features from a built-in microphone for acoustic instruments and tone generation to a wide tuning range for everything fr ...

Also dont give up. Chords are one of the hardest things to get at first but are really necessary. And change your strings every couple months cause the older they are, the easier they get out of tune.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I got it. I was trying to do the simple time of your life beat (Where you strum all strings and just change chords) that many people said was good for beginners etc. Well one strum on the g chord doesnt sound anything like the ones in the video. I have the standard e a d g b e tune so i think i dont have the right tune set for the song… or it just sounds different coming from a laptop.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 21, 2009, 06:46:41 pm[/size][hr]Unhandled helped me tune it and now it sounds great

Read full topic

@Frell wrote:

Lol.

Im having trouble doing the G chord. My middle finger usually touches the A a little, and when i fix it the A string buzzes. I cant do much changing because its like making a retarded nigger eagle claw and hurts my wrist and im positive it isnt natural. Does anyone have an alternative?

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:30, topic:303278”][quote author=Frell link=topic=399605.msg2964773#msg2964773 date=1253479894]
Owow. i can play smoke on the water, and im working on the POC theme right now. Im having a hard time tuning the E string for pirates though :S
[/quote]Link to where you learned smoke on the water.

IMO, you should keep updating this post with the resources you use as you learn. That way it can be a resource for anyone with the same problem as you, or even someone just looking to learn some guitar.[/quote]

Oh i mean just a part of smoke on the water, meaning the most famous part

0-3-5-0-3-6-5-0-3-5-3-0 pm from eh pretty easy

And can anyone help me with tuning my guitar for Pirates of the Caribbean? I cant really do it by ear yet

After realizing that i had a hard time holding down frets with multiple fingers i remembered i really only wanted to learn 2 songs… and i never really liked guitars. Not because of how hard they are to play, its just i don’t like things that have physical limitations. Im probably going to take it back etc. Im not giving up, i’d just rather not waste my time.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

a bit contradictory, as those are both steel-string guitars

while it is true that steel will be a bit rough on your fingers to start with (as in, the actual skin on the end of you fingers will be a bit scuffed and sore for the first week or two that you’re learning) that goes away pretty quick as the skin callouses up, and steel-string guitars are often much easier to play after this happens because they have lower action (the strings are closer to the fretboard so less movement is required to push them down)

lower action also makes barre chords easier (which is going to be one of your first stumbling blocks, probably)

personally i’d recommend, if you’re not that bothered eitherway, to get a steel-string. everybody always suggests nylon strings to young people/people starting out, and i’ve never understood why, theyre harder to play and they don’t sound like most people are expecting unless they want to play a lot of classical stuff. literally the only thing they have going for them is that they don’t make your fingertips sore, and thats hardly worth the trouble since it goes away after a few weeks

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yes, but which type of acoustic? Nylon string classical guitars and steel-string modern acoustics play differently and sound differently

Perhaps if you told us what sort of music you’d be playing?

Read full topic

item.title: Guitars and finger length
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:303278”]if you buy a first act you will find it much harder to learn, because those really cheap acoustics play like ASS

seriously, do yourself a favour and take it seriously if youre gonna take it seriously

not saying you have to buy a stupidly expensive instrument, but one of the budget yamahas or takamines or fenders or w/e shouldnt cost too much and will play a lot better than that first act shit

EDIT: also, i dunno if you noticed, but the behringer you linked is a steel-string, not a classical. which one do you want? i or others could give a couple of recommendations for cheap guitars, then[/quote]
I’ve already noted that first act is shit and im going to avoid it, and i will be looking out for yamahas, fenders, takamines, Ibanez, and Epiphones.

We have to take my uncle to the airport later today, and i told my mom about your opinions on walmart and she said there is a music store up by the mall and we can run in.

A cheap guitar in a quality music store is probably better than a 150$ guitar at walmart.


Acoustic is what i want.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 20, 2009, 07:27:28 am[/size][hr]http://www.coastalgrand.com/shop/coastal.nsf/StoresAlphaWebNums/Andy+Owings+Music+Center338

Brand Names:

Yamaha; Pearl River; Ludwig; Rhythm Art; Fender; Paul Reid Smith; Alvarez; Takamine; Ibanez; Taylor; Schecter; Samick; Tama; Ampeg; Hartke and Line 6

Perfect.

http://shopping.andyowingsmusic.info/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=CTGY&Store_Code=AOMC&Category_Code=210

Nope, over my price limit ugh

even though im avoiding first act: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xFLSPNHUMK8 it doesnt sound that bad.

Read full topic
